awd_titl_txt: Adapting Tested Spatial Skills Curriculum to On-Line Format for Community College Instruction: A Critical Link to Retain Technology Students

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Spatial Visualization Skills (SVS) include translating 2-D objects to 3-D and mentally rotating 3-D objects; skills important to many disciplines, including advanced technology fields. SVS exhibit robust gender differences, favoring males. Students from low SES and disproportionately underrepresented minority (URM) groups are also at risk for poorly developed SVS. Low SVS among women and URM likely impact our ability to broaden participation in technician education programs. Even good students can have poor spatial skills, which can be a barrier to learning and success in STEM fields.

Although people with poor spatial skills believe it is something “they are just not good at”, SVS are malleable and can be learned. In studies of students in four-year engineering programs, students who improve SVS persist at a higher rate than students with weak SVS who do not improve their skills.

This project researched the effectiveness for technical education students, of the on-line Developing Spatial Thinking course, which includes: 10 curricular modules, voice-over-PowerPoint mini-lectures, “getting started” videos, and sketching assignments, available at Higher Education Services (https://www.higheredservices.org/). The on-line format allows students to fit training into busy schedules and organizations to offer SVS training with nominal resources.

Also examined, was the effectiveness of an SVS sketching app developed at UC, San Diego. The team received an NSF SBIR Phase I grant for their newly-formed company (www.egrove.education) to continue to develop this SVS training tool. The Spatial Vis™ app is available in the App Store and Google Play.

Over the course of seven semesters, faculty at four community colleges (Baltimore County Community College, Del Mar College, McHenry County College, Tidewater Community College) assessed students’ SVS using the Purdue Spatial Visualization Test: Rotation (PSVT:R) and offered training to students with weak skills.

Need for SVS Training of Technical Education Students is Evident

  • 1,491 students (17% women, 23% Hispanic, 10% African American, 7% Asian, 55% White) in technical education programs completed the PSVT:R.
  • 63% of students scored 70% or below, indicating weak spatial skills and eligibility for the SVS course:
    • a higher percentage of women (82% vs 59% men) scored 70% or below
    • a higher percentage of Hispanic (70%), African American (79%) and Asian (68%) students as compared to White (56%) students scored 70% or below
    • 184 (20%) of students eligible for the course, completed the SVS training

SVS Training Outcomes

Of students who completed the course, 20% were women, 21% Hispanic, 26% African American, 9% Asian, and 20% White. Students who completed the SVS training course earned:

  • a statistically significant higher score on the post PSVT:R (61% correct vs 52% correct)
  • a higher grade in their credit bearing technical education course (B vs. C grade)
  • a higher overall GPA (3.0 vs 2.8) than eligible students who did not take the SVS training.

Although eligible students who completed the training had stronger graduation and retention rates than eligible students who did not receive training, the differences were not statistically significant.

SVS Training Course:  Student Feedback

92% of all student participants responded to a post-training survey. The vast majority had positive views about the materials, topics and exercises:

  • 98% agreed that the course was engaging
  • 90% agreed that the class improved their spatial skills
  • 91% would recommend the class
  • 92% would recommend the materials
  • 86% agreed that what they learned will help them in other courses 

 A key finding is the importance of instructor support to student success. Students in technology education programs did not find an exclusively online SVS intervention compelling. Few students completed the course when offered online-only. The support of the instructor to learn the material, practice drawing, and provide encouragement and guidance is very important, a finding consistent over the years of implementation. The final product is a hybrid course that combines on-line materials with face-to-face interaction.

iPad App:  Student Feedback

Faculty were pleased with the spatial skills iPad app and reported no concerns with device and app management. Students enjoyed the app as a supplement to paper-and-pencil sketching.  Of 66 survey respondents who used the iPad app, the majority had an overwhelmingly positive opinion of its usefulness and the immediate grading of sketching assignments.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impact

The NSF ATE-funded project shows evidence of the need for an SVS intervention for technology education students. This short-term, 10-module intervention, with online materials and lectures, provides a way for faculty to support the development of important, often-ignored skills, and impact students’ grades and progress towards degree. The positive feedback and observed outcomes suggest that this intervention could have a broad impact on technology education. Faculty in many degree programs (engineering technology, manufacturing, digital media, robotics, computer-aided drafting and design technology, CNC machining) could embed the SVS curriculum and online materials within required introductory courses to increase the opportunity for students to improve their SVS and complete their degree.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2018
Modified by: Susan S Metz
